tables.title: Table 1
tables.caption: Relationship between gradient similarity and catastrophic forgetting. Results are reported as Number of forgotten questions (Percentage). Samples with negative gradient similarity are ranked by magnitude: top 1/3 are Sim, bottom 1/3 are Dissim.

tables.title: Table 1 Evolution
tables.caption: Evolution of Table 1 over training epochs. Marker size encodes forgotten-question count (#SIM/#DISSIM) while line height encodes forgotten-question percentage.

tables.title: Table 2
tables.caption: Distribution of collaborative neurons (COLL) and conflicting neurons (CONF). PROP denotes neuron-type proportion. GRAD denotes gradient similarity sum for that type. TOTAL denotes the gradient similarity sum over all neurons.

tables.title: Table 3
tables.caption: Effectiveness of knowledge injection using FT and CNL. Results are reported as Number of questions (Percentage). FT tends to forget previously mastered knowledge, while CNL induces negligible catastrophic forgetting.

tables.title: Table 4
tables.caption: Impact of different optimizers on catastrophic forgetting. Results are reported as Number of questions (Percentage).

texts.title: Paper Comparison Appendix (Simple)
texts.content:
Quick read (simple language):

1) What these results mean in practical and conceptual terms:
- Practical: Forgetting drops a lot with CNL (FT 88.30% -> CNL 17.47%).
- Practical: New learning is also much lower with CNL (FT 28.97% -> CNL 4.98%).
- Conceptual: On this small model, CNL behaves like a strong stability control. It protects old knowledge, but it also limits plasticity.
- Mechanism hint from Table 1: Sim has more forgetting in 1/4 datasets.
- Mechanism hint from Table 2: Conflicting neurons are more common in 4/4 datasets.

2) How this compares to the original paper (larger models):
- Direction matches: CNL still reduces forgetting compared with FT.
- In this SmolLM run, forgetting is about 80.2% lower with CNL, but learning is about 82.8% lower.
- Difference from paper trend: the large-model paper shows strong forgetting control without such a large learning drop.
- So this is a partial reproduction, not a full quantitative match.

3) Are trends consistent with the original findings? If not, why might they differ?
- Partly consistent: CNL < FT on forgetting.
- Partly inconsistent: CNL learning is much lower here than the paper suggests.
- Likely reasons:
- Small model has less spare capacity, so stability controls can block learning more strongly.
- Same training recipe from bigger models may not be optimal at this scale.
- One model size and one config are not enough to average out run variance.
- Table 2 values are normalized in this pipeline, while the paper reports signed sums.

4) What we can and cannot conclude (scalability, robustness, mechanism):
- Can conclude (robustness): CNL robustly reduces forgetting versus FT in this run.
- Can conclude (mechanism, directional): conflict-heavy structure still appears (Table 2), but weaker.
- Cannot conclude (scalability): we cannot claim large-model behavior from one small-model setting.
- Cannot conclude (mechanism, strict): we need exact metric parity and multi-seed checks.
- Cannot conclude (final quality): this is a strong diagnostic result, not the final endpoint.
